R-type (Cav2.3, residual current)
T-type (Cav3.1, low-voltage activated)
questions.explanation: P/Q-type Ca2+ channels (Cav2.1) are the primary trigger for neurotransmitter release at most fast central synapses. They are concentrated at presynaptic active zones, tethered by RIM-BP scaffold proteins, and positioned in nanometer proximity to the SNARE/synaptotagmin release machinery. Cav2.1 has favorable biophysical properties for coupling to release: high single-channel conductance, fast activation upon depolarization, and expression of both P-type (in cerebellar Purkinje cells, blocked by omega-agatoxin IVA) and Q-type (broader CNS distribution) splice variants. N-type Ca2+ channels (Cav2.2, blocked by omega-conotoxin GVIA) also contribute at some synapses, particularly in the PNS and some central synapses. Mutations in CACNA1A (Cav2.1 gene) cause familial hemiplegic migraine, episodic ataxia type 2, and spinocerebellar ataxia type 6. L-type channels are important for gene expression and muscle contraction. T-type channels contribute to rhythmic firing in thalamus.

questions.question: The concept of the 'reversal potential' is fundamental to understanding synaptic currents. What determines the reversal potential of a synaptic current?
options: The threshold for action potential generation
The resting membrane potential of the postsynaptic cell
The concentration of neurotransmitter in the synaptic cleft
The weighted average of equilibrium potentials for all ions conducted by the receptor channel, according to their relative permeabilities
questions.explanation: The reversal potential (Erev) of a synaptic current is the membrane potential at which the net current through the receptor channel is zero — it reverses direction at this voltage. It is determined by the relative permeabilities of the channel for different ions, calculated using the Goldman equation. For AMPA receptors (permeable to Na+ and K+ approximately equally), Erev is approximately 0 mV (the average of ENa and EK). For GABA_A/glycine receptors (Cl--selective), Erev equals ECl (approximately -80 mV). For NMDA receptors (permeable to Ca2+, Na+, K+), Erev is approximately +10 mV. For nAChRs, Erev is approximately -5 to 0 mV. Knowing Erev allows prediction of whether a synaptic input will be excitatory (Erev above threshold) or inhibitory (Erev below threshold), and the direction and magnitude of synaptic currents at any holding potential (I = g × (Vm - Erev)).

questions.question: In an experiment measuring compound action potentials (CAPs) from a peripheral nerve, two distinct peaks are observed: Peak A arrives first with higher amplitude, and Peak B arrives later with lower amplitude. When the nerve is cooled, the latency of both peaks increases, but Peak B is more affected. When a low concentration of lidocaine is applied, Peak B disappears first while Peak A persists. What explains these two peaks?
options: Peak A and B represent EPSPs and IPSPs respectively

Peak A represents fast-conducting large-diameter myelinated axons (A-alpha fibers), while Peak B represents slower, small-diameter thinly myelinated or unmyelinated axons (C fibers); smaller fibers are more sensitive to local anesthetics and temperature
Peak A is a measurement artifact and Peak B is the real signal
Peak A represents sensory axons and Peak B represents motor axons
questions.explanation: Peripheral nerves contain axons of different diameters and myelination status, each with different conduction velocities. A compound action potential (CAP) represents the summed extracellular signal from all activated axons. Peak A represents the fastest-conducting fibers — large-diameter, heavily myelinated A-alpha fibers (12-20 um diameter, 70-120 m/s), which include proprioceptive and motor axons. Peak B represents slower fibers — small-diameter, thinly myelinated A-delta fibers (1-5 um, 5-30 m/s) or unmyelinated C fibers (0.2-1.5 um, 0.5-2 m/s). Cooling reduces conduction velocity proportionally more in smaller fibers because they have less safety factor (fewer Na+ channels per node). Lidocaine blocks smaller fibers first because: (1) their higher surface-to-volume ratio allows faster drug penetration; (2) they have fewer nodes so blocking a few nodes causes complete block; (3) they fire at higher frequencies (more use-dependent block).

questions.question: A voltage-clamp experiment measures Na+ currents at different test potentials. At -20 mV, a small inward current is observed. At 0 mV, the current is larger. At +20 mV, the current is smaller again. At +55 mV, no current flows. At +80 mV, an outward current is observed through Na+ channels. What explains this non-monotonic current-voltage relationship?
options: Na+ channels become K+-selective at positive potentials
The inward rectification property of Na+ channels prevents outward current

The Na+ current depends on both the number of open channels (which increases with depolarization) and the driving force (Vm - ENa, which decreases and then reverses as Vm approaches and exceeds ENa), producing a peak current near -20 to 0 mV
Different Na+ channel subtypes activate at different voltages
questions.explanation: The Na+ current through voltage-gated channels is determined by: INa = gNa × (Vm - ENa), where gNa = gNa_max × m³h (the voltage-dependent conductance). Two opposing factors create the non-monotonic I-V curve: (1) As Vm becomes more positive, more Na+ channels activate (m increases), increasing gNa. (2) As Vm approaches ENa (+55 mV), the driving force (Vm - ENa) decreases, reducing the current per open channel. At ENa, the driving force is zero and no net current flows despite maximum channel opening. Above ENa (e.g., +80 mV), the driving force reverses (Vm > ENa), so Na+ flows outward through any remaining open channels. The peak inward current typically occurs around -20 to 0 mV, representing the optimal balance between channel activation and driving force. This I-V relationship was first characterized by Hodgkin and Huxley and is fundamental to understanding excitable membranes.

questions.question: To determine whether a specific gene expressed in neurons is required for learning and memory, a researcher needs to knock it out specifically in hippocampal excitatory neurons of adult mice (to avoid developmental effects). Which genetic strategy would achieve this?
options: A tamoxifen-inducible, Cre-lox conditional knockout system using CaMKII-CreERT2 (expressed in excitatory neurons) crossed with floxed allele mice, with tamoxifen administered in adulthood
Constitutive global knockout of the gene from birth
CRISPR injection into the zygote to create a global knockout
Antisense oligonucleotide injection into the ventricles
questions.explanation: The tamoxifen-inducible conditional knockout provides temporal (adult-specific) and spatial (excitatory neuron-specific) control. The system requires: (1) Mice carrying the target gene flanked by loxP sites (floxed allele) — generated by homologous recombination in ES cells or CRISPR. (2) A CaMKII-CreERT2 transgenic line expressing Cre recombinase fused to a modified estrogen receptor (ERT2) under the CaMKII-alpha promoter (active in forebrain excitatory neurons). CreERT2 is sequestered in the cytoplasm until tamoxifen administration causes nuclear translocation, where Cre excises the floxed gene. (3) Tamoxifen is administered in adulthood, allowing normal development before gene deletion. After a suitable washout period, mice undergo behavioral testing (Morris water maze, contextual fear conditioning) to assess learning/memory. Controls include floxed-only mice (no Cre) and oil-injected CreERT2 mice. Global knockouts may be embryonic lethal or cause developmental compensation.

questions.question: A researcher has a fluorescent Ca2+ indicator (GCaMP) expressed in neurons and wants to determine whether observed Ca2+ transients in dendritic spines during synaptic stimulation are mediated by NMDA receptors, voltage-gated Ca2+ channels, or internal Ca2+ stores. Which pharmacological experiment would distinguish these three sources?
options: Apply a high concentration of EGTA to chelate all Ca2+
Replace extracellular Ca2+ with Ba2+ and repeat the stimulation

Sequentially apply: (1) APV (NMDA blocker) to test NMDA contribution, (2) cadmium or specific VGCC blockers to test voltage-gated Ca2+ channel contribution, (3) thapsigargin (SERCA pump inhibitor) to deplete ER stores, measuring the reduction in Ca2+ signal at each step
Block all synaptic transmission with TTX and observe if Ca2+ transients disappear
questions.explanation: Sequential pharmacological dissection allows quantification of each Ca2+ source. (1) APV (D-2-amino-5-phosphonovalerate), a specific NMDA receptor antagonist, blocks Ca2+ influx through NMDA receptors. The fraction of the Ca2+ transient eliminated by APV represents the NMDA receptor contribution. (2) Adding voltage-gated Ca2+ channel blockers (Cd2+ for non-selective block, or specific blockers: nimodipine for L-type, omega-agatoxin for P/Q-type, omega-conotoxin for N-type) in the presence of APV reveals the VGCC contribution. (3) Thapsigargin irreversibly inhibits SERCA (sarco/endoplasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase), depleting ER Ca2+ stores over time. Any remaining Ca2+ signal sensitive to thapsigargin represents Ca2+-induced Ca2+ release (CICR) from internal stores. Alternatively, ryanodine receptor blockers (ryanodine) or IP3 receptor blockers (xestospongin C) can be used. TTX blocks all action potentials and is too nonspecific for this question.

questions.question: Tetanus toxin and botulinum toxin both target SNARE proteins but produce opposite clinical symptoms. What accounts for this difference?
options: Tetanus toxin enhances neurotransmitter release while botulinum toxin inhibits it
They cleave different SNARE proteins
Tetanus toxin only affects sensory neurons while botulinum toxin affects motor neurons

Tetanus toxin is transported retrogradely from NMJs to inhibitory interneurons in the spinal cord where it cleaves VAMP2, blocking inhibitory neurotransmitter release (causing spastic paralysis), while botulinum toxin acts locally at the NMJ to block excitatory transmission (causing flaccid paralysis)
questions.explanation: Both toxins are zinc-dependent proteases produced by Clostridium species and both cleave SNARE proteins to block vesicle fusion. However, their different clinical effects arise from different sites of action: Botulinum toxin (BoNT) acts locally at the neuromuscular junction, blocking ACh release from motor neuron terminals, causing flaccid paralysis (no muscle contraction). Tetanus toxin (TeNT) enters motor neuron terminals at the NMJ but is then transported retrogradely (via dynein) to the cell body in the spinal cord. From there, it undergoes transcytosis into inhibitory (glycinergic and GABAergic) interneuron terminals, where it cleaves VAMP2 (synaptobrevin-2). This blocks inhibitory neurotransmitter release, removing inhibition from motor neurons and causing uncontrolled, sustained muscle contraction (spastic paralysis, tetanic spasms). Both toxins actually cleave synaptobrevin, but their trafficking determines the clinical phenotype.

questions.question: Dendritic spines are the primary sites of excitatory synaptic input in the mammalian brain. What is the functional significance of the spine neck geometry?
options: The narrow spine neck creates a diffusional barrier and electrical compartment that biochemically and electrically isolates individual synapses, allowing synapse-specific plasticity
Spine necks facilitate direct electrical coupling between dendrites
Spine necks store neurotransmitter vesicles for retrograde release
Spine necks increase the speed of synaptic transmission
questions.explanation: Dendritic spines (0.5-2 um in length) have a bulbous head connected to the dendritic shaft by a thin neck (50-200 nm diameter). The narrow neck serves critical compartmentalization functions: (1) Biochemical compartmentalization — the neck restricts diffusion of signaling molecules (Ca2+, activated CaMKII, Ras, cAMP) generated at the synapse, confining them to the individual spine head. This enables synapse-specific plasticity: one spine can undergo LTP while adjacent spines are unaffected. (2) Electrical compartmentalization — the high resistance of the narrow neck creates a voltage compartment, meaning EPSPs generated at the spine head are attenuated (filtered) as they spread to the dendrite. This may allow local voltage-dependent processes (NMDA receptor unblock) at individual spines. Spine morphology is dynamic: LTP causes spine enlargement (mushroom spines), while LTD causes spine shrinkage. Spine loss and dysmorphology are hallmarks of neurodegenerative diseases and intellectual disability syndromes.

questions.question: The tripartite synapse model includes the astrocyte as an active participant in synaptic signaling. How do astrocytes modulate synaptic transmission?
options: Astrocytes generate action potentials that propagate to neurons

Astrocytes detect neuronal activity via Ca2+ elevations, release gliotransmitters (glutamate, D-serine, ATP) that modulate pre- and postsynaptic function, and regulate extracellular K+ and glutamate concentrations
Astrocytes replace neurons as the primary signal transmitters
Astrocytes only provide structural support and have no signaling function
questions.explanation: The tripartite synapse model (proposed by Bhatt, Bhatt, and Bhatt, and developed by many groups) recognizes astrocytic perisynaptic processes as active modulatory elements. Astrocytes detect synaptic activity through metabotropic receptors (mGluRs, purinergic receptors, endocannabinoid receptors) that trigger intracellular Ca2+ elevations via IP3-dependent ER release. Ca2+ elevations trigger release of gliotransmitters: (1) D-serine, an NMDA receptor co-agonist that modulates LTP; (2) glutamate, which can activate presynaptic mGluRs and extrasynaptic NMDA receptors; (3) ATP/adenosine, which modulates presynaptic release via P2Y and A1 receptors. Astrocytes also provide essential homeostatic functions: glutamate uptake (EAAT1/2), K+ buffering (Kir4.1 channels), and regulation of extracellular volume. Astrocytes communicate with each other via gap junctions (Cx43/Cx30) forming a syncytium. They do not generate action potentials but exhibit Ca2+ waves.

questions.question: Nodes of Ranvier have a specific molecular organization essential for saltatory conduction. Which proteins are enriched at the node versus the paranode and juxtaparanode?
options: All types of ion channels are uniformly distributed along the axon
Only neurofascin is found at nodes with no other specific organization
K+ channels at nodes and Na+ channels at paranodes
Nav1.6 channels and ankyrin-G/betaIV-spectrin at nodes; Caspr/contactin and paranodal junction proteins at paranodes; Kv1.1/Kv1.2 channels at juxtaparanodes
questions.explanation: Nodes of Ranvier have a highly organized molecular architecture divided into distinct domains: (1) Nodes: High density of Nav1.6 channels (~1,000/um²), organized by the scaffold protein ankyrin-G (AnkG), which also recruits betaIV-spectrin, the cell adhesion molecule neurofascin-186 (NF186), and NrCAM. KCNQ2/3 (Kv7.2/7.3) channels also cluster at nodes. (2) Paranodes: Septate-like junctions formed by the interaction of axonal Caspr (contactin-associated protein)/contactin with glial neurofascin-155 (NF155). These junctions form a diffusion barrier preventing lateral migration of nodal channels. (3) Juxtaparanodes: Kv1.1 and Kv1.2 channels are clustered beneath the myelin, organized by Caspr2 and TAG-1. These Kv channels prevent re-excitation and regulate axonal excitability. Disruption of paranodal junctions (e.g., in demyelinating diseases) allows Kv1 channels to redistribute into the nodal region, causing conduction failure.

questions.question: Homeostatic synaptic plasticity (synaptic scaling) maintains neural circuit stability. When chronic activity is reduced (e.g., by TTX application for 48 hours), what compensatory change occurs at excitatory synapses?
options: Only NMDA receptors are upregulated while AMPA receptors remain unchanged

All AMPA receptor currents are multiplicatively scaled up (increased surface AMPA receptor expression), while GABA receptor expression is scaled down, restoring the neuron's firing rate toward its set point
The neuron permanently ceases to fire
Synaptic AMPA receptors are removed to further reduce activity
questions.explanation: Homeostatic synaptic scaling is a form of negative feedback that stabilizes neural circuit activity. When chronic activity is reduced (TTX block, sensory deprivation), neurons upregulate postsynaptic AMPA receptor expression at all excitatory synapses multiplicatively — each synapse's strength is scaled up by a common factor, preserving the relative differences between synapses (unlike Hebbian plasticity which changes specific synapses). The mechanisms involve: (1) increased GluA1/GluA2 surface expression through TNF-alpha signaling and Arc/Arg3.1 downregulation; (2) increased mEPSC (miniature EPSC) amplitude; (3) decreased GABA_A receptor surface expression (scaling down inhibition). Conversely, chronically elevated activity triggers scaling down (reduced AMPA receptors, increased inhibition). This bidirectional scaling maintains firing rates within a functional range. The set point is thought to involve Ca2+-dependent sensors and transcription factors (CREB, MeCP2). Disrupted homeostatic plasticity may contribute to epilepsy and autism.

questions.question: Which property of the NMDA receptor makes it a 'coincidence detector' critical for Hebbian learning ('neurons that fire together wire together')?
options: NMDA receptors only open during sleep
NMDA receptors require simultaneous presynaptic glutamate release AND postsynaptic depolarization (to relieve Mg2+ block), detecting the temporal coincidence of pre- and postsynaptic activity
NMDA receptors are activated by dopamine rather than glutamate
NMDA receptors detect mechanical vibrations at the synapse
questions.explanation: NMDA receptors are molecular coincidence detectors because they require two simultaneous conditions for activation: (1) Presynaptic activity — glutamate must be released and bind to the NMDA receptor (along with the co-agonist glycine/D-serine). (2) Postsynaptic depolarization — the postsynaptic membrane must be sufficiently depolarized to expel the Mg2+ ion that blocks the channel pore at resting potential. This typically requires concurrent AMPA receptor activation at the same or nearby synapses. Only when both conditions are met does Ca2+ flow through the NMDA receptor, triggering LTP. This implements Hebb's rule: synapses where the presynaptic neuron contributes to firing the postsynaptic neuron are selectively strengthened. Synapses where presynaptic activity occurs without sufficient postsynaptic depolarization do not activate NMDA receptors and are not potentiated. This associative property is fundamental to learning, memory formation, and activity-dependent circuit refinement during development.

questions.question: Benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam/Valium) are anxiolytic and sedative drugs that act on GABA_A receptors. What is their specific mechanism of action?
options: They bind to a specific allosteric site (between alpha and gamma subunits) and increase the frequency of GABA-mediated channel openings without changing single-channel conductance or open duration
They block GABA reuptake transporters to increase GABA levels
They inhibit GABA transaminase to prevent GABA degradation
They directly open GABA_A channels without GABA being present
questions.explanation: Benzodiazepines are positive allosteric modulators (PAMs) of GABA_A receptors. They bind to a specific site located at the interface between alpha (alpha1, 2, 3, or 5, NOT alpha4 or alpha6) and gamma2 subunits — distinct from the GABA binding site (between alpha and beta subunits). Benzodiazepine binding enhances GABA's ability to open the channel by increasing the frequency of channel opening events (without affecting single-channel conductance or mean open time). Critically, benzodiazepines have no effect in the absence of GABA — they are pure modulators, not direct agonists, which limits their maximum effect and provides a safety margin compared to barbiturates (which increase open duration and CAN directly open channels at high doses). Different alpha subunit combinations confer different pharmacological effects: alpha1 (sedation/amnesia), alpha2/3 (anxiolysis), alpha5 (memory). This explains why newer drugs (zolpidem/Ambien) targeting alpha1-containing receptors are sedative-selective.

questions.question: Ephaptic coupling is a form of neural communication that does not require chemical synapses or gap junctions. What is the mechanism?
options: Mechanical transmission of vibrations through the extracellular matrix
Direct electrical field effects from one neuron's activity influencing neighboring neurons through extracellular current flow, without any physical connection
Communication via astrocyte-mediated metabolite transfer
Communication through blood-borne hormones
questions.explanation: Ephaptic coupling occurs when the extracellular currents generated by one neuron's electrical activity (action potentials or synaptic potentials) influence the excitability of nearby neurons without any direct synaptic or gap junction connection. When an action potential propagates, it generates ionic currents in the extracellular space. If neurons are packed tightly (as in cortical columns, hippocampus, or peripheral nerve bundles), these extracellular fields can be large enough to depolarize or hyperpolarize adjacent neurons by a few millivolts — sufficient to modulate firing probability. Ephaptic effects are particularly significant in: (1) myelinated nerve bundles where paranodal currents from one fiber can affect neighbors; (2) densely packed cortical/hippocampal pyramidal cell layers; (3) the cerebellum (Purkinje-basket cell interactions). Local field potentials (LFPs) and EEG signals represent these summed extracellular currents. Ephaptic coupling may contribute to neural synchronization, seizure propagation, and cross-talk in nerves.

questions.question: Neurotransmitter receptors can be desensitized following prolonged or repeated agonist exposure. What is the molecular mechanism of AMPA receptor desensitization?
options: Upon sustained glutamate binding, AMPA receptor subunits undergo a conformational change where the ligand-binding domain (LBD) dimer interface rearranges, causing the ion channel pore to close despite glutamate remaining bound
Desensitization requires phosphorylation by all known kinases
AMPA receptors are proteolytically cleaved and degraded
AMPA receptors are immediately internalized by endocytosis upon glutamate binding
questions.explanation: AMPA receptor desensitization is an intrinsic conformational transition of the receptor protein. Each GluA subunit has a bilobed ligand-binding domain (LBD) that clamps shut upon glutamate binding. In the resting state, the LBD dimer interface (between adjacent subunits) is stable. Upon glutamate binding and channel opening, strain accumulates at the dimer interface. Within milliseconds, the dimer interface ruptures, allowing the LBDs to rotate and rearrange, which decouples ligand binding from channel gating — the pore closes even though glutamate is still bound. This is desensitization (distinct from deactivation, which occurs when glutamate unbinds). The rate of desensitization is extremely fast for AMPA receptors (~1-10 ms), which is important for shaping the time course of synaptic currents. Cyclothiazide (a positive allosteric modulator) blocks desensitization by stabilizing the LBD dimer interface. The drug perampanel is a negative allosteric modulator used to treat epilepsy. Receptor internalization is a slower process (minutes) mediating LTD.

questions.question: The neurotransmitter acetylcholine acts through two fundamentally different receptor classes. What distinguishes nicotinic from muscarinic ACh receptors?
options: Both are ionotropic channels but conduct different ions
Both are GPCRs but couple to different G-proteins
Nicotinic receptors are inhibitory and muscarinic are excitatory

Nicotinic receptors are ionotropic (pentameric ligand-gated cation channels) producing fast EPSPs, while muscarinic receptors are metabotropic (GPCRs) producing slow modulatory effects through G-protein signaling cascades
questions.explanation: Nicotinic ACh receptors (nAChRs) are ligand-gated ion channels (ionotropic) — pentameric assemblies of homologous subunits forming a central cation-permeable pore. Upon ACh binding, the channel opens within microseconds, conducting Na+ and K+ (and some Ca2+), producing a fast EPSP. There are muscle-type (alpha1-beta-epsilon-delta) and neuronal (alpha2-10, beta2-4) nAChRs. Muscarinic ACh receptors (M1-M5) are seven-transmembrane GPCRs that signal through heterotrimeric G-proteins over seconds to minutes. M1, M3, M5 couple to Gq (activating PLC-IP3/DAG-Ca2+), while M2, M4 couple to Gi/o (inhibiting adenylyl cyclase, activating GIRK channels). Muscarinic effects are slower but longer-lasting and can be either excitatory (M1, closing M-type K+ channels) or inhibitory (M2, opening GIRK channels in heart). Named after their respective agonists: nicotine selectively activates nAChRs; muscarine (mushroom alkaloid) selectively activates mAChRs.

questions.question: During high-frequency synaptic transmission, the readily releasable pool (RRP) of synaptic vesicles can become depleted. What replenishes the RRP?
options: The RRP is not replenished and synaptic transmission ceases permanently
New vesicles are synthesized de novo in the nerve terminal
Vesicles are directly transferred from neighboring synapses

Vesicles from the reserve pool are mobilized to the RRP through synapsin phosphorylation (by CaMKII) releasing them from the actin cytoskeleton, and recycled vesicles from endocytosis re-enter the RRP
questions.explanation: The RRP (readily releasable pool, ~5-20 vesicles per active zone) is replenished from two sources: (1) Reserve pool mobilization: The majority of synaptic vesicles (~80-90%) are tethered to the actin cytoskeleton by synapsin proteins, forming the reserve pool. During sustained activity, elevated Ca2+ activates CaMKII and CaMKIV, which phosphorylate synapsin at multiple sites (Ser566, Ser603), reducing its affinity for both vesicles and actin. This releases reserve vesicles, which then dock and prime at active zones to refill the RRP. CDK5 also phosphorylates synapsin. (2) Vesicle recycling: After exocytosis, vesicle membrane is retrieved by clathrin-mediated endocytosis, and recycled vesicles are re-acidified and refilled with neurotransmitter by the V-ATPase and vesicular transporters before re-entering the RRP. The balance between RRP depletion (exocytosis rate) and replenishment (recycling + mobilization rate) determines whether a synapse shows depression or facilitation during trains of stimuli.

questions.question: What is the ionic basis of the end-plate potential (EPP) at the neuromuscular junction, and why does the EPP always depolarize the muscle fiber?
options: The EPP is caused by Na+/K+ ATPase inhibition at the end-plate
The EPP is caused by Ca2+ influx through L-type channels
The EPP is caused by Cl- influx through nAChRs

nAChRs are non-selective cation channels permeable to both Na+ and K+, with a reversal potential near 0 mV; since 0 mV is far above the muscle resting potential (-90 mV), the net current is always inward (depolarizing)
questions.explanation: Nicotinic ACh receptors at the NMJ are non-selective cation channels approximately equally permeable to Na+ and K+ (PNa/PK approximately 1.1). The reversal potential (Erev) for the EPP is approximately -5 to 0 mV (approximately midway between ENa of +55 mV and EK of -90 mV). Since the muscle fiber resting potential is approximately -90 mV, which is far below Erev, there is always a large inward driving force when nAChRs open. Na+ influx dominates (because of the larger electrochemical gradient for Na+ at -90 mV), producing a robust depolarization (EPP typically 40-70 mV, well above the ~-50 mV threshold for muscle action potential). The EPP has a large safety factor — even if 70% of receptors are blocked (as in mild myasthenia gravis), the remaining EPP still reaches threshold. Only when receptor loss exceeds 70-80% does neuromuscular transmission fail.

questions.question: Alpha-latrotoxin, from black widow spider venom, causes massive neurotransmitter release at the neuromuscular junction. What is its mechanism?
options: It inhibits acetylcholinesterase to prolong ACh action
It blocks K+ channels causing prolonged depolarization

Alpha-latrotoxin forms Ca2+-permeable pores in the presynaptic membrane (via neurexin/latrophilin receptors) and stimulates massive vesicle exocytosis both through Ca2+ influx and by a Ca2+-independent mechanism involving direct interaction with the release machinery
It activates postsynaptic receptors directly to mimic neurotransmitter action
questions.explanation: Alpha-latrotoxin (alpha-LTX) from Latrodectus spiders binds to presynaptic receptors (neurexin and latrophilin/CIRL) and inserts into the presynaptic membrane, forming Ca2+-permeable pores (tetrameric channels). This has two consequences: (1) Ca2+-dependent mechanism: Ca2+ influx through the alpha-LTX pores triggers massive vesicle exocytosis through the normal synaptotagmin-SNARE machinery. (2) Ca2+-independent mechanism: Alpha-LTX can stimulate release even in Ca2+-free conditions, likely through direct interaction with the SNARE/Munc18/Munc13 machinery and by mechanical membrane deformation. The result is explosive, uncontrolled neurotransmitter release that depletes all vesicle pools, initially causing intense muscle contraction (from ACh flood at NMJs) followed by paralysis (from vesicle depletion). Clinically, black widow spider bites cause intense pain, muscle spasms, and autonomic dysfunction. Alpha-LTX has been invaluable as a research tool for studying vesicle release mechanisms.

questions.question: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) like fluoxetine (Prozac) are the most prescribed antidepressants. What is their molecular target and mechanism?
options: SSRIs inhibit monoamine oxidase to prevent serotonin degradation
SSRIs selectively block the serotonin transporter (SERT/5-HTT), preventing serotonin reuptake from the synaptic cleft, increasing extracellular serotonin levels at serotonergic synapses
SSRIs activate serotonin receptors as direct agonists
SSRIs block serotonin synthesis by inhibiting tryptophan hydroxylase
questions.explanation: SSRIs selectively block the serotonin transporter (SERT, SLC6A4), a Na+/Cl--dependent plasma membrane transporter that normally terminates serotonergic signaling by reuptaking 5-HT back into the presynaptic terminal. By blocking SERT, SSRIs increase the concentration and duration of serotonin in the synaptic cleft, enhancing serotonergic transmission. SSRIs show high selectivity for SERT over other monoamine transporters (DAT, NET), unlike older tricyclic antidepressants that block multiple transporters. However, there is a therapeutic delay of 2-4 weeks before clinical improvement, suggesting that the acute increase in 5-HT levels triggers downstream adaptive changes: initially, increased 5-HT activates inhibitory 5-HT1A autoreceptors on raphe neurons, reducing firing. Over weeks, autoreceptors desensitize, firing increases, and downstream receptor adaptations (BDNF upregulation, neurogenesis, receptor sensitization changes) produce the antidepressant effect. MAOIs are a different class that prevent intracellular 5-HT degradation.

questions.question: Sensory receptor potentials are graded potentials that encode stimulus intensity. In mechanoreceptors like Pacinian corpuscles, what ion channel type transduces mechanical stimuli into electrical signals?
options: Ligand-gated glutamate receptors
Voltage-gated Na+ channels
ATP-gated P2X channels
Mechanically gated cation channels (Piezo2 and possibly DEG/ENaC family) that open in response to membrane stretch or deformation
questions.explanation: Mechanosensory transduction in Pacinian corpuscles and other mechanoreceptors involves specialized ion channels that open in response to mechanical forces — membrane stretch, pressure, or deformation. The Piezo family (Piezo1 and Piezo2, discovered by Ardem Patapoutian, Nobel Prize 2021) are key mechanotransduction channels. Piezo2 is essential for light touch sensation and proprioception. These are large trimeric channels with unique propeller-like structure (~38 transmembrane segments per subunit) that respond to membrane tension by conformational change, opening a central non-selective cation pore permeable to Na+, K+, and Ca2+. The resulting depolarizing receptor potential (generator potential) is graded — proportional to stimulus intensity. If the receptor potential reaches threshold at the first node of Ranvier, it triggers action potentials. The Pacinian corpuscle's layered onion-like capsule provides rapid adaptation by filtering sustained pressure into onset/offset transients. DEG/ENaC channels contribute to mechanosensation in some contexts (e.g., nematode touch neurons).

questions.question: A current-clamp recording from a hippocampal pyramidal neuron shows that injecting 100 pA of depolarizing current produces 5 action potentials per second, while 200 pA produces 15 APs/s, and 300 pA produces 25 APs/s. This linear relationship between input current and firing rate is called the f-I (frequency-current) curve. However, when a constant depolarizing current of 200 pA is maintained for 30 seconds, the firing rate gradually decreases from 15 to 5 APs/s. What explains this firing rate adaptation?
options: Glutamate depletion in the recording electrode causes reduced stimulation
The neuron enters a permanent refractory state

Spike-frequency adaptation is caused by activation of slow afterhyperpolarization (AHP) currents, primarily through Ca2+-activated K+ channels (SK and BK channels) and M-type K+ channels (Kv7/KCNQ), which accumulate and progressively hyperpolarize the neuron
The Na+/K+ ATPase completely fails during prolonged stimulation
questions.explanation: Spike-frequency adaptation is a fundamental property of most neurons that prevents excessive firing during sustained stimulation. The mechanism involves slow K+ currents that build up during repetitive firing: (1) Ca2+-activated K+ channels (SK channels, activated by Ca2+/calmodulin; BK channels, activated by Ca2+ and voltage) open as intracellular Ca2+ accumulates from repeated action potentials. These channels generate the slow afterhyperpolarization (sAHP) and medium AHP (mAHP) that follow each spike, and their cumulative effect progressively raises the inter-spike interval. (2) M-type K+ channels (Kv7.2/Kv7.3, KCNQ2/3), slow voltage-gated K+ channels that activate near threshold and generate a persistent outward current (M-current) that opposes depolarization. (3) Na+ channel slow inactivation also contributes over seconds, reducing the available Na+ channel pool. The balance of these mechanisms varies by neuron type — fast-spiking interneurons show minimal adaptation (due to Kv3 channels enabling fast recovery), while pyramidal neurons show prominent adaptation.

questions.question: Researchers use paired recordings (simultaneously recording from a presynaptic and postsynaptic neuron) to study synaptic properties. When the presynaptic neuron fires 100 action potentials, EPSPs are observed in the postsynaptic neuron only 30 times (30% success rate). The amplitude of successful EPSPs varies between 0.5-2.0 mV, but clusters around multiples of approximately 0.4 mV (0.4, 0.8, 1.2, 1.6 mV). What do these observations reveal about synaptic transmission?
options: The 70% failure rate indicates postsynaptic receptor desensitization
The synapse is malfunctioning and needs more neurotransmitter

The 30% success rate reflects a low release probability (Pr = 0.3), and the amplitude clustering at multiples of ~0.4 mV reflects quantal release — each quantum (~0.4 mV, equivalent to one vesicle) is released with probability p, and multiple quanta can be released simultaneously, producing the observed amplitude distribution
The varying amplitudes indicate different types of postsynaptic receptors
questions.explanation: This experiment demonstrates the quantal nature of synaptic transmission at a central synapse. The key observations: (1) Probabilistic release: The 30% success rate (70% failures) reflects the stochastic nature of vesicle fusion. Each release site has a probability p of releasing a vesicle for each action potential. At central synapses, p (release probability) is typically 0.1-0.5 per release site. (2) Quantal amplitude: The clustering of EPSP amplitudes at multiples of ~0.4 mV indicates that each released vesicle (quantum) contributes approximately 0.4 mV to the EPSP. When 1 vesicle fuses: 0.4 mV; 2 vesicles: 0.8 mV; 3 vesicles: 1.2 mV; etc. The amplitude histogram shows peaks at these quantal multiples (Poisson distribution). This is described by the binomial model: the synapse has n release sites, each with probability p, giving mean quantal content m = np. With m = np ≈ 0.3-0.5, most events are single quantal releases with occasional multi-quantal events. This quantal analysis, pioneered by del Castillo and Katz at the NMJ, is fundamental to understanding synaptic function.

questions.question: A researcher measures action potential conduction velocity in a peripheral nerve fiber under different conditions. Normal velocity: 50 m/s. After partial demyelination of a 2 mm segment: velocity drops to 5 m/s through that segment. After complete demyelination of the same segment: conduction block (no propagation). After treatment with 4-aminopyridine (a K+ channel blocker): partial restoration of conduction through the demyelinated segment. Why does 4-AP restore conduction in partially demyelinated nerves?
options: 4-AP enhances remyelination by oligodendrocytes
4-AP increases axon diameter to improve current flow

By blocking Kv1 channels that become exposed (redistributed from juxtaparanodes to demyelinated regions), 4-AP prevents K+ efflux that opposes depolarization, allowing the weakened action potential to reach threshold at the next node
4-AP increases Na+ channel density at nodes
questions.explanation: In normally myelinated axons, Kv1.1/Kv1.2 channels are sequestered under the myelin at juxtaparanodes, where they regulate excitability but don't directly oppose action potential propagation. When myelin is lost, paranodal junctions are disrupted, and Kv1 channels redistribute laterally into the now-exposed internodal membrane. These exposed Kv1 channels activate during the action potential, conducting K+ outward and opposing the depolarizing Na+ current. In partially demyelinated nerves, the reduced membrane resistance already weakens passive current spread; the additional K+ shunt from exposed Kv1 channels further reduces the safety factor below 1, causing conduction block. 4-aminopyridine blocks Kv1 channels, removing this opposing K+ current and partially restoring the safety factor, allowing (slowed) action potential propagation. 4-AP (dalfampridine/Ampyra) is FDA-approved for improving walking in multiple sclerosis patients. It cannot restore normal velocity but can convert conduction block to slow conduction.

questions.question: To create a complete connectome (wiring diagram) of a small neural circuit, a researcher needs to identify all synaptic connections between neurons. Which technique provides the most comprehensive structural connectivity data?
options: Serial-section electron microscopy (ssEM) or focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy (FIB-SEM) to reconstruct all neurons and synapses at nanometer resolution in a volume of tissue
Calcium imaging to detect functional connections
EEG recording to detect electrical correlations
Functional MRI (fMRI) to detect correlated neural activity
questions.explanation: Serial-section electron microscopy (ssEM) and focused ion beam SEM (FIB-SEM) are the gold standard for structural connectomics because they provide the resolution (~4 nm in x-y, ~30-50 nm in z for ssEM; ~8 nm isotropic for FIB-SEM) needed to visualize and reconstruct every neuronal process and identify every chemical synapse (characterized by presynaptic vesicle clusters, synaptic cleft, and postsynaptic density) and electrical synapse (gap junctions) in a tissue volume. The complete C. elegans connectome (302 neurons) was mapped by John White using ssEM in 1986. Modern efforts have mapped large portions of the Drosophila brain and mouse cortical columns using automated serial sectioning and machine learning-assisted segmentation. fMRI and EEG detect correlated activity but cannot resolve individual synapses or determine wiring. Calcium imaging reveals functional connections but misses subthreshold connections and cannot determine synapse type or number. Light microscopy lacks the resolution to identify individual synapses.

questions.question: A pharmaceutical company wants to develop a new analgesic (pain-relieving drug) that targets the voltage-gated Na+ channel Nav1.7, which is specifically expressed in nociceptors and essential for pain sensation. What is the main challenge in developing Nav1.7-selective blockers?
options: Nav1.7 is only expressed during embryonic development, not in adults
Pain cannot be treated by blocking a single ion channel subtype
Nav1.7 is not a real drug target because it has no role in pain

Nav1.7 shares >70% sequence identity with other Nav subtypes (Nav1.1-Nav1.6, Nav1.8-Nav1.9) expressed in brain, heart, and skeletal muscle; achieving selectivity to avoid cardiac arrhythmias (Nav1.5), seizures (Nav1.1/Nav1.2), and motor impairment (Nav1.4) requires exploiting subtle structural differences in the voltage-sensing domain or pore module between subtypes
questions.explanation: The nine mammalian voltage-gated Na+ channel subtypes (Nav1.1-Nav1.9) share a highly conserved pore structure (the target of current Na+ channel blockers like lidocaine, which lack subtype selectivity). Developing Nav1.7-selective inhibitors is challenging because: (1) High sequence homology: The pore and local anesthetic binding site are >85% conserved across subtypes. (2) Safety concerns: Non-selective block of Nav1.5 (cardiac) causes fatal arrhythmias; Nav1.1 block causes seizures (Dravet syndrome); Nav1.4 block causes paralysis. (3) Structural differences are subtle: Nav subtypes differ primarily in the voltage-sensing domains (S1-S4), the extracellular loops, and kinetic properties. Strategies include targeting subtype-specific residues in the voltage sensor (VSD4), using spider/scorpion toxin scaffolds that naturally show subtype selectivity, or designing state-dependent blockers that preferentially bind Nav1.7's unique inactivated-state conformation. Several Nav1.7-selective compounds are in clinical trials.

questions.question: To determine the reversal potential of a synaptic current and thereby identify which ions carry the current, a researcher performs voltage-clamp recordings while stimulating the presynaptic neuron. The postsynaptic cell is held at different potentials. At what holding potential is the reversal potential measured?
options: The potential where the synaptic current is maximum
The potential where the cell fires an action potential
The holding potential where the evoked synaptic current reverses direction (changes from inward to outward or vice versa), indicating zero net current flow through the receptor channels
The resting membrane potential of the cell
questions.explanation: The reversal potential (Erev) is determined by systematically varying the holding potential in voltage-clamp mode while repeatedly evoking synaptic currents. At potentials below Erev, the synaptic current flows in one direction (typically inward for excitatory currents). At potentials above Erev, the current reverses direction (becomes outward). At exactly Erev, the net synaptic current is zero because there is no net driving force on the permeant ions. Plotting peak synaptic current amplitude vs. holding potential (the I-V curve) gives a line or curve that crosses zero at Erev. The measured Erev reveals the ion selectivity: Erev near 0 mV indicates a non-selective cation channel (excitatory, like AMPA/NMDA/nAChR); Erev near ECl (-80 mV) indicates a Cl- channel (inhibitory, like GABA_A/GlyR); Erev near EK (-90 mV) indicates a K+-selective conductance. Pharmacological isolation (blocking other conductances) ensures clean measurement.

questions.question: In a paired-pulse experiment at a synapse, the researcher delivers two stimuli separated by 50 ms and measures the EPSC amplitudes. At one synapse (type X), the second EPSC is 200% of the first (PPR = 2.0). At another synapse (type Y), the second EPSC is 60% of the first (PPR = 0.6). What can be inferred about the initial release probability at each synapse?
options: The PPR differences reflect postsynaptic receptor desensitization
Both synapses have identical release probabilities
Type X is excitatory and type Y is inhibitory
Type X has a low initial release probability (showing facilitation due to residual Ca2+), while type Y has a high initial release probability (showing depression due to partial RRP depletion)
questions.explanation: The paired-pulse ratio (PPR) is a reliable indicator of initial release probability (Pr). At low-Pr synapses (type X): Few vesicles fuse on the first pulse, leaving the readily releasable pool (RRP) largely intact. Residual Ca2+ from the first pulse adds to Ca2+ from the second pulse, increasing Pr for the second stimulus. The second EPSC is larger (PPR > 1 = facilitation). At high-Pr synapses (type Y): Many vesicles fuse on the first pulse, significantly depleting the RRP. Even though residual Ca2+ may increase Pr slightly, the reduced number of available vesicles dominates, producing a smaller second EPSC (PPR < 1 = depression). This presynaptic mechanism is confirmed if PPR changes inversely correlate with changes in first EPSC amplitude (e.g., reducing external Ca2+ increases PPR and decreases first EPSC). Postsynaptic mechanisms (receptor desensitization, saturation) can also contribute but are typically ruled out pharmacologically. PPR analysis is widely used to determine whether experimental manipulations act pre- or postsynaptically.

questions.question: A neuroscientist records from a neuron and observes spontaneous miniature excitatory postsynaptic currents (mEPSCs) in the presence of TTX (which blocks action potentials). The mean mEPSC amplitude is 15 pA and frequency is 2 Hz. After treating the culture with BDNF for 24 hours, the mean mEPSC amplitude increases to 25 pA but frequency remains 2 Hz. What does this indicate?
options: BDNF enhances postsynaptic responsiveness, likely by increasing AMPA receptor number or conductance at each synapse, without affecting presynaptic vesicle release rate
BDNF increases the number of synapses
BDNF increases presynaptic release probability
BDNF increases vesicle size and neurotransmitter content
questions.explanation: mEPSCs represent the postsynaptic response to spontaneous release of single synaptic vesicles (quanta). Their amplitude reflects postsynaptic factors (receptor number, receptor conductance, spine geometry), while their frequency reflects presynaptic factors (number of release sites and spontaneous vesicle fusion rate). In this experiment: (1) mEPSC amplitude increased from 15 to 25 pA — this indicates enhanced postsynaptic responsiveness, most likely increased AMPA receptor density at individual synapses or increased single-channel conductance (consistent with BDNF's known effects on GluA1 surface expression and phosphorylation). (2) mEPSC frequency remained unchanged at 2 Hz — this indicates no change in the rate of spontaneous vesicle fusion events, suggesting no change in release probability or synapse number. Together, this demonstrates a purely postsynaptic effect of BDNF. If the frequency had also increased, this would suggest additional presynaptic effects or synaptogenesis.

questions.question: A researcher calculates the equilibrium potential for Na+ using the Nernst equation at 37°C: [Na+]out = 145 mM, [Na+]in = 12 mM. The calculated ENa = +66 mV. During the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential only reaches +35 mV. Given that ENa is +66 mV, why does the peak not reach ENa?
options: At the peak, the membrane is not exclusively permeable to Na+; residual K+ permeability and the beginning of K+ channel opening prevent the membrane from reaching ENa, as predicted by the GHK equation
The Nernst equation is incorrect for Na+
Na+ channels are completely blocked at +35 mV
The Na+ gradient has been significantly depleted by the action potential
questions.explanation: The Nernst equation predicts the equilibrium potential for a single ion species when the membrane is exclusively permeable to that ion. However, during the peak of the action potential, the membrane is not exclusively permeable to Na+: (1) K+ leak channels remain open throughout, maintaining some K+ permeability (PK > 0). (2) Delayed rectifier K+ channels begin activating during the rising phase (they have slow kinetics but start opening near the peak). (3) The GHK equation, which accounts for multiple permeable ions, predicts: Vm = (RT/F) × ln[(PNa[Na]o + PK[K]o)/(PNa[Na]i + PK[K]i)]. Even when PNa >> PK, the non-zero PK pulls the membrane potential away from ENa toward EK. At the peak, PNa/PK ≈ 20:1 (not infinity), so Vm reaches approximately +35 mV rather than +66 mV. Additionally, Na+ channel inactivation begins reducing gNa even at the peak. The Na+ gradient depletion during a single AP is negligible (<0.001% change).

questions.question: Dopamine signaling in the mesolimbic pathway is implicated in reward processing and addiction. Dopamine acts through D1-like (D1, D5) and D2-like (D2, D3, D4) receptor families. What is the fundamental difference between these two families?
options: Both families are identical in their signaling cascades
D1-like receptors couple to Gs proteins (stimulating adenylyl cyclase and increasing cAMP), while D2-like receptors couple to Gi/Go proteins (inhibiting adenylyl cyclase and decreasing cAMP)
D1-like receptors are ionotropic and D2-like are metabotropic
D1-like receptors are excitatory and D2-like have no physiological function
questions.explanation: All dopamine receptors are GPCRs (7-transmembrane), but they diverge into two families with opposite effects on the cAMP pathway: D1-like family (D1, D5) couples to Gs/Golf, activating adenylyl cyclase, increasing cAMP, and activating PKA. This leads to phosphorylation of DARPP-32, which amplifies kinase signaling and modulates ion channel function and gene expression (via CREB). D2-like family (D2, D3, D4) couples to Gi/Go, inhibiting adenylyl cyclase, decreasing cAMP, and reducing PKA activity. D2 receptors also activate GIRK channels (via Gbetagamma) and inhibit voltage-gated Ca2+ channels. D2 autoreceptors on dopaminergic neuron terminals and soma/dendrites reduce dopamine release and firing. Antipsychotic drugs (haloperidol, risperidone) primarily block D2 receptors. L-DOPA (converted to dopamine) activates both families to treat Parkinson's disease. The D1-D2 balance in striatal medium spiny neurons (direct vs. indirect pathway) is critical for movement control.

questions.question: What is the molecular mechanism by which organophosphate nerve agents (sarin, VX) cause death?
options: They block GABA_A receptors, causing seizures
They block voltage-gated Na+ channels, preventing all neural signaling
They activate NMDA receptors directly, causing excitotoxicity

They irreversibly phosphorylate the active-site serine of acetylcholinesterase, causing ACh accumulation at all cholinergic synapses, leading to sustained depolarization at NMJs (paralysis), bronchospasm, excessive secretions, and seizures
questions.explanation: Organophosphate nerve agents (sarin, tabun, soman, VX) are potent irreversible inhibitors of acetylcholinesterase (AChE). They covalently phosphorylate the catalytic serine residue (Ser203 in human AChE) in the enzyme's active site, permanently inactivating it. Without AChE to degrade ACh, ACh accumulates at all cholinergic synapses: (1) NMJ: Sustained depolarization block → skeletal muscle paralysis, including respiratory muscles; (2) Parasympathetic effectors: Excessive glandular secretions (salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation = SLUDGE), bronchospasm, bradycardia; (3) CNS: Seizures, unconsciousness. Death typically results from respiratory failure (diaphragm paralysis + bronchospasm + excessive secretions). Treatment includes: atropine (competitive muscarinic antagonist to block parasympathetic effects), pralidoxime/2-PAM (nucleophilic oxime that can reactivate phosphorylated AChE if given before 'aging'), and diazepam (for seizures). After 'aging' (loss of alkyl group from phosphorylated serine), the enzyme is permanently inactivated.

questions.question: The concept of 'safety factor' in neuromuscular transmission refers to the excess of EPP amplitude over the threshold needed to trigger a muscle action potential. The normal safety factor is approximately 3-4x. What molecular mechanisms maintain this high safety factor?
options: Only a few ACh receptors are present at the NMJ

High quantal content (m ≈ 50-300 vesicles per impulse), high nAChR density at junctional folds (~10,000/um²), and high AChE activity ensuring rapid ACh clearance all contribute to a reliable, reproducible suprathreshold EPP
The safety factor depends solely on the diameter of the motor neuron axon
Muscle fibers have extremely low action potential thresholds
questions.explanation: The neuromuscular junction is designed for reliable, fail-safe transmission through multiple redundant mechanisms: (1) High quantal content: Each nerve impulse releases 50-300 synaptic vesicles (quanta) simultaneously from hundreds of active zones, producing a large EPP (typically 40-70 mV). (2) High receptor density: nAChRs are concentrated at ~10,000 receptors/um² on the crests of junctional folds (maintained by agrin-MuSK-rapsyn signaling), ensuring maximum responsiveness to released ACh. (3) Junctional folds: The postsynaptic membrane is folded, with nAChRs on the crests and voltage-gated Na+ channels (Nav1.4) concentrated in the troughs, positioning them to be activated by the EPP. (4) High AChE activity: Rapid ACh degradation prevents receptor desensitization from prolonged ACh exposure. The safety factor (~3-4x) means the EPP exceeds threshold by 3-4 fold. Myasthenia gravis reduces the safety factor below 1, causing transmission failure.

questions.question: The HCN (hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated) channels carry the Ih current. What unusual property distinguishes HCN channels from other voltage-gated channels?
options: HCN channels are activated by membrane hyperpolarization rather than depolarization, conducting a mixed Na+/K+ inward current that depolarizes the cell back toward threshold
HCN channels are activated by very strong depolarization beyond +50 mV
HCN channels are selectively permeable to Cl-
HCN channels are only found in cardiac cells, not neurons
questions.explanation: HCN channels (HCN1-4) are unique among the voltage-gated channel superfamily because they are activated by membrane HYPERPOLARIZATION rather than depolarization — the opposite of most voltage-gated channels. They activate slowly at potentials below -50 to -60 mV and conduct a mixed Na+/K+ current (Erev approximately -30 mV). Because Erev is above resting potential, Ih activation during hyperpolarization produces an inward depolarizing current that opposes and limits the hyperpolarization. This gives HCN channels a critical role in: (1) Pacemaking: In cardiac sinoatrial node cells and thalamic relay neurons, Ih produces the slow depolarization between beats/bursts; (2) Setting resting potential: Ih depolarizes neurons from EK toward firing threshold; (3) Dendritic integration: Ih in dendrites normalizes the temporal summation of distal EPSPs. cAMP binding to the cyclic nucleotide-binding domain (CNBD) shifts the activation curve positive, linking neuromodulation (via Gs-coupled receptors → cAMP) to pacemaker frequency. HCN channels are found in both heart and brain.

questions.question: Kainate receptors are the third class of ionotropic glutamate receptors. How do they differ functionally from AMPA and NMDA receptors at synapses?
options: Kainate receptors are only found in invertebrates
Kainate receptors are exclusively inhibitory Cl- channels
Kainate receptors have identical properties to AMPA receptors

Kainate receptors can function both as conventional ionotropic channels (fast cation current) and through a non-canonical metabotropic signaling pathway involving G-proteins, and they play important roles in presynaptic modulation of both excitatory and inhibitory transmission
questions.explanation: Kainate receptors (assembled from GluK1-5 subunits) have unique dual signaling capabilities. As ionotropic channels, they conduct Na+ and K+ (and Ca2+ for some subunit combinations), but with slower kinetics and smaller currents than AMPA receptors. Uniquely, kainate receptors also signal through a non-canonical metabotropic pathway involving Gi/Go proteins, which can modulate transmitter release and membrane excitability. Key roles include: (1) Presynaptic modulation at both excitatory (reducing glutamate release at high agonist concentrations) and inhibitory (reducing GABA release at hippocampal interneuron synapses) terminals; (2) Contribution to slow EPSCs at mossy fiber-CA3 synapses; (3) Regulation of neuronal excitability by inhibiting the slow afterhyperpolarization. Kainate receptor dysfunction is implicated in epilepsy (GluK2 variants), and kainic acid injection causes seizures by overstimulating these receptors. CNQX blocks both AMPA and kainate receptors, while GYKI compounds selectively block AMPA receptors.

questions.question: What is the structural basis for the voltage-dependent Mg2+ block of the NMDA receptor channel?
options: Mg2+ enters the channel pore from the extracellular side and is trapped at a binding site formed by asparagine residues (N+1 site) in the M2 re-entrant pore loop of GluN2 subunits, where the electrical field keeps it bound at negative potentials
Mg2+ binds to the extracellular surface of the receptor and prevents glutamate binding
Mg2+ blocks the channel from the intracellular side
Mg2+ prevents NMDA receptor assembly in the ER
questions.explanation: The voltage-dependent Mg2+ block is mediated by a specific binding site within the NMDA receptor channel pore. Mg2+ ions (~1 mM extracellular) enter the pore from the outside and bind at the 'N+1 site' — a narrow constriction formed by asparagine residues in the M2 re-entrant pore loop of each GluN2 subunit (and corresponding sites on GluN1 subunits). At resting potentials (-70 mV), the strong inward electrical field drives Mg2+ deep into the pore but it cannot pass through the narrow selectivity region, becoming trapped and blocking the channel. As the membrane depolarizes, the electrical driving force on Mg2+ decreases, and at potentials above -40 to -20 mV, Mg2+ is expelled from the pore (primarily outward into the cytoplasm), relieving the block. This voltage-dependent relief of block creates the characteristic region of negative slope conductance in the NMDA receptor I-V curve. GluN2A subunits show stronger Mg2+ block than GluN2C/2D, contributing to subunit-dependent differences in NMDA receptor function.

questions.question: Neuronal chloride homeostasis is critical for determining the polarity of GABAergic signaling. Which two transporters are the primary regulators of intracellular Cl- concentration in neurons?
options: Cl-/HCO3- exchanger and the Na+/K+ ATPase
GABA transporters GAT-1 and GAT-3
NKCC1 (Na-K-2Cl cotransporter, imports Cl-) and KCC2 (K-Cl cotransporter, exports Cl-), with their relative expression levels determining intracellular Cl- and thus GABA polarity
CFTR and ClC-2 chloride channels
questions.explanation: Neuronal intracellular Cl- concentration is set by the balance of two cation-chloride cotransporters: (1) NKCC1 (SLC12A2): Uses the Na+ gradient to import Na+, K+, and 2Cl- into the cell, raising intracellular Cl-. Highly expressed in immature neurons. (2) KCC2 (SLC12A5): Uses the K+ gradient to export K+ and Cl-, lowering intracellular Cl-. Upregulated during postnatal development. In immature neurons: NKCC1 >> KCC2, so intracellular Cl- is high (~25-40 mM), ECl is positive (approximately -40 mV), and GABA is depolarizing/excitatory. In mature neurons: KCC2 >> NKCC1, so intracellular Cl- is low (~5 mM), ECl is negative (approximately -80 mV), and GABA is hyperpolarizing/inhibitory. Dysregulation of this balance is implicated in epilepsy (reduced KCC2), neuropathic pain (BDNF-mediated KCC2 downregulation in spinal cord), and neurodevelopmental disorders. Bumetanide (NKCC1 inhibitor) is being investigated as an adjunctive antiepileptic therapy.

questions.question: Autapses are synapses that a neuron makes onto itself. What potential function do autapses serve in neural circuits?
options: Autapses only exist in invertebrate nervous systems
Autapses provide self-feedback that can either reinforce (excitatory autapses) or dampen (inhibitory autapses) a neuron's own firing, contributing to precise spike timing and circuit dynamics
Autapses have no function and are developmental errors
Autapses transmit signals to glial cells
questions.explanation: Autapses are functional self-synapses where a neuron's axon forms synaptic contacts back onto its own dendrites or soma. Once considered rare curiosities, autapses are now recognized as relatively common, particularly in cortical and hippocampal fast-spiking interneurons. Excitatory autapses (on principal neurons) provide positive feedback that can reinforce and prolong firing. Inhibitory autapses (on GABAergic interneurons, which are the most well-studied) provide negative feedback that sharpens spike timing and contributes to gamma oscillations (30-80 Hz). In fast-spiking basket cells, inhibitory autapses through GABA_A receptors limit the number of spikes in a burst and help regulate the precise timing of inhibitory output to the circuit. Computational models suggest autapses can stabilize network dynamics and prevent epileptiform activity. Autapses have been found in both vertebrate and invertebrate nervous systems (including the C. elegans connectome).

questions.question: The Nernst equation uses the ratio of extracellular to intracellular ion concentrations. For a divalent cation like Ca2+ ([Ca2+]out = 2 mM, [Ca2+]in = 100 nM), what is the approximate equilibrium potential ECa at 37°C?
options: +65 mV
+30 mV
questions.explanation: The Nernst equation for Ca2+ (z = +2) is: ECa = (RT/zF) × ln([Ca2+]out/[Ca2+]in) = (26.7/2) × ln(2 mM / 0.0001 mM) = 13.35 × ln(20,000) = 13.35 × 9.90 = +132 mV, approximately +128 mV. The key points: (1) Because Ca2+ is divalent (z = 2), the prefactor is halved compared to monovalent ions (26.7/2 = 13.35 mV instead of 26.7 mV). (2) The enormous concentration gradient (20,000:1 ratio, compared to ~30:1 for Na+) produces a very positive equilibrium potential. This means the electrochemical driving force on Ca2+ is very large at all physiological membrane potentials — both the concentration gradient and electrical gradient drive Ca2+ inward. This is why even brief opening of Ca2+ channels produces significant Ca2+ influx, and why intracellular Ca2+ is such an effective signaling molecule (small absolute changes represent large relative changes from the 100 nM baseline).

questions.question: Neuromodulators like acetylcholine, norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine differ from classical fast neurotransmitters in their mode of action. What is the concept of 'volume transmission'?
options: Volume transmission refers to the total amount of neurotransmitter released per second
Neurotransmitters are released in exact amounts proportional to the volume of the synaptic cleft

Neuromodulators diffuse from release sites through the extracellular space to act on receptors over a wide area (hundreds of micrometers), affecting many cells simultaneously, in contrast to point-to-point 'wired transmission' at classical synapses
Volume transmission is synonymous with electrical transmission through gap junctions
questions.explanation: Volume transmission (also called extrasynaptic or paracrine transmission) describes a mode of intercellular communication where neurotransmitters or neuromodulators diffuse through the extracellular space to reach receptors distant from the release site, rather than acting only at the confined synaptic cleft. Monoamines (dopamine, norepinephrine, serotonin) are prime examples: they are often released from varicosities (non-junctional release sites along axons) and can diffuse >100 um to act on extrasynaptic receptors on multiple cell types (neurons, astrocytes, blood vessels). Volume transmission produces slower, longer-lasting, and more diffuse effects compared to 'wired transmission' (classical point-to-point synaptic transmission with <50 nm cleft width). The balance between release rate, diffusion distance, uptake (by transporters), and receptor affinity determines the spatial and temporal extent of volume transmission. Nitric oxide and endocannabinoids are extreme examples of volume transmitters due to their membrane permeability.

questions.question: Which structural and functional properties allow invertebrate giant axons (such as the squid giant axon, ~1 mm diameter) to achieve rapid action potential conduction without myelination?
options: Giant axons use Ca2+ instead of Na+ for action potentials
Giant axons conduct signals passively without action potentials

The large diameter dramatically reduces axoplasmic resistance (Ri ∝ 1/r²), increasing the length constant and allowing faster passive current spread, achieving conduction velocities of ~25 m/s — though still slower than vertebrate myelinated axons of much smaller diameter
Giant axons have a fundamentally different Na+ channel with faster kinetics
questions.explanation: The squid giant axon (~500-1000 um diameter) was an evolutionary solution to the need for fast conduction to power the jet-propelled escape response, achieved without myelination. The biophysical advantage of large diameter lies in reducing axoplasmic resistance: Ri is proportional to 1/cross-sectional area (= 1/pi*r²), so a 500 um axon has ~10,000 times lower Ri than a 5 um axon. The length constant (lambda = sqrt(Rm/Ri)) increases dramatically, allowing passive current from one active region to spread farther and faster, regenerating the action potential at more distant points. The squid giant axon achieves ~25 m/s — adequate for an escape response. However, this is inefficient in terms of space and metabolic cost. Vertebrate myelination achieves even faster speeds (~100 m/s) with axons only 10-20 um diameter, by increasing Rm and decreasing Cm at internodes. The squid giant axon's accessibility (visible to the naked eye) made it ideal for Hodgkin and Huxley's Nobel Prize-winning experiments.

questions.question: Metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) are classified into three groups. Which group includes mGluR1 and mGluR5, and what is their signaling mechanism?
options: Group I mGluRs are nuclear receptors that directly regulate gene transcription
Group I mGluRs are ionotropic channels that conduct Ca2+
Group I mGluRs couple to Gs and stimulate cAMP production
Group I mGluRs (mGluR1, mGluR5) couple to Gq proteins, activating PLC-beta to produce IP3 (releasing Ca2+ from ER stores) and DAG (activating PKC)
questions.explanation: Metabotropic glutamate receptors are grouped by sequence homology, pharmacology, and G-protein coupling: Group I (mGluR1, mGluR5): Couple to Gq/G11 → activate PLC-beta → produce IP3 + DAG. IP3 releases Ca2+ from ER stores via IP3 receptors; DAG activates PKC. Group I mGluRs are predominantly postsynaptic and generally excitatory — they enhance neuronal excitability by closing K+ channels, potentiating NMDA receptor currents, and mobilizing endocannabinoid synthesis. mGluR5 is essential for some forms of LTD (mGluR-LTD). Group II (mGluR2, mGluR3) and Group III (mGluR4, mGluR6, mGluR7, mGluR8): Couple to Gi/Go → inhibit adenylyl cyclase, reduce cAMP. These are predominantly presynaptic autoreceptors that reduce glutamate release and are potential drug targets for anxiety and schizophrenia. mGluR6 in ON-bipolar cells of the retina is unusual — it uses a Gao pathway to close TRPM1 cation channels in the dark.

questions.question: Neurons can encode information through different firing patterns. What is 'burst firing' and which ion channels enable it?
options: Burst firing is simply high-frequency regular firing above 100 Hz
Burst firing only occurs during seizures and has no physiological role

Burst firing consists of clusters of action potentials riding on a depolarizing plateau, enabled by T-type (low-voltage activated) Ca2+ channels that generate low-threshold spikes upon deinactivation from hyperpolarized potentials
Burst firing requires gap junction coupling between neurons
questions.explanation: Burst firing is a distinct firing mode where neurons produce clusters (bursts) of 2-7 action potentials at high frequency (~200-400 Hz within burst), separated by silent intervals. The key channel enabling burst firing is the T-type (transient, low-threshold) Ca2+ channel (Cav3.1/3.2/3.3). T-type channels have unique biophysics: they activate at relatively negative potentials (-65 to -40 mV, hence 'low-voltage activated'), rapidly inactivate, and recover from inactivation (deinactivate) only during hyperpolarization below -70 mV. When a neuron is hyperpolarized (e.g., by GABA inhibition), T-type channels deinactivate. Upon return toward threshold, T-type channels open, generating a broad low-threshold Ca2+ spike that carries a burst of Na+ action potentials on its crest. This is critical for: thalamic relay neurons (burst mode during sleep, tonic mode during wakefulness), rhythmic oscillations (delta, spindle waves), and hippocampal burst firing that enhances synaptic plasticity. The transition between tonic and burst modes is controlled by membrane potential (and neuromodulators that shift the potential).

questions.question: An experiment using optogenetics activates channelrhodopsin (ChR2) in a specific population of hippocampal neurons with different light intensities. At low light intensity (1 mW/mm²), small photocurrents (~50 pA) are generated but no action potentials are fired. At moderate intensity (5 mW/mm²), photocurrents of ~200 pA are generated and the neuron fires action potentials. At high intensity (20 mW/mm²), photocurrents of ~500 pA generate high-frequency firing. What does this demonstrate about neural coding?
options: Light intensity directly determines neurotransmitter type

The graded photocurrent from ChR2 activation mimics physiological synaptic input: subthreshold currents produce graded depolarizations, while suprathreshold currents produce action potentials whose frequency increases with stimulus intensity, demonstrating the conversion of analog (graded potential) to digital (frequency-coded) information at the axon hillock
Higher light intensity changes the channel selectivity of ChR2
Action potentials at different light intensities have different amplitudes
questions.explanation: This optogenetics experiment elegantly demonstrates the fundamental principle of neural coding at the single-neuron level: the conversion from analog to digital (frequency) coding. ChR2 generates graded photocurrents proportional to light intensity (more photons → more channels open → larger current). At the soma/axon hillock, these graded depolarizations interact with the threshold mechanism: Below threshold: The depolarization spreads passively and decays without generating an AP. Above threshold: Each time the membrane reaches threshold, an AP is generated (all-or-none, constant amplitude). Higher stimulus intensity produces larger depolarization, which reaches threshold more quickly after each AP (shorter interspike interval), resulting in higher firing frequency. This rate coding is the primary way neurons encode stimulus intensity — stronger stimuli produce higher firing rates, not larger APs. The f-I (frequency-current) relationship is approximately linear over a neuron's dynamic range. This principle, demonstrated here with optogenetics, applies equally to physiological sensory coding and synaptic integration.

questions.question: A researcher records excitatory postsynaptic currents (EPSCs) at a hippocampal synapse using voltage clamp at -70 mV. The EPSC has two distinct kinetic components: a fast component (rise time 0.5 ms, decay time 3 ms) and a slow component (rise time 5 ms, decay time 100 ms). Adding 50 uM APV (NMDA receptor antagonist) completely eliminates the slow component but leaves the fast component unchanged. Adding 10 uM CNQX (AMPA/kainate receptor antagonist) to the APV eliminates the remaining fast component. What do these results reveal?
options: The slow component represents postsynaptic calcium spikes

The fast EPSC component is mediated by AMPA receptors (CNQX-sensitive) and the slow component by NMDA receptors (APV-sensitive); both receptor types coexist at the same synapse and are activated simultaneously by glutamate release, contributing to distinct temporal phases of the postsynaptic response
The synapse only uses one receptor type
Both components are mediated by the same receptor with different states
questions.explanation: This pharmacological dissection demonstrates the dual component nature of glutamatergic EPSCs. Most excitatory synapses in the hippocampus contain both AMPA and NMDA receptors that are activated simultaneously by glutamate release from the same presynaptic terminal. However, they produce temporally distinct current components: (1) AMPA component (fast): Rapidly activated, produces peak current within ~1 ms, and decays quickly (~3-5 ms). Mediates the bulk of fast synaptic transmission and determines whether the postsynaptic cell reaches threshold. Blocked by CNQX/NBQX. (2) NMDA component (slow): Activates more slowly (partially due to slower channel kinetics and voltage-dependent Mg2+ block relief), produces a smaller peak but sustained current lasting ~100-200 ms. At -70 mV holding potential, the Mg2+ block is largely relieved by the voltage clamp, revealing the full NMDA current. Blocked by APV/MK-801. The NMDA component provides the Ca2+ signal for synaptic plasticity (LTP/LTD). This dual receptor system allows the same synapse to mediate both fast transmission and long-term plasticity.

questions.question: A neuroscientist records intracellular potentials from a postsynaptic neuron while stimulating presynaptic excitatory and inhibitory inputs. Stimulating the excitatory input alone produces a 10 mV EPSP. Stimulating the inhibitory input alone produces no visible change in membrane potential (the cell stays at -70 mV, and ECl = -70 mV). However, when both inputs are stimulated simultaneously, the EPSP amplitude is reduced to only 5 mV. How does the inhibitory input reduce the EPSP without producing a visible IPSP?
options: The inhibitory input causes presynaptic inhibition of the excitatory terminal

This is shunting inhibition: the inhibitory input opens Cl- channels at ECl = Vm, producing no voltage change alone but increasing membrane conductance (reducing input resistance), which shunts (short-circuits) the excitatory current, reducing the amplitude of the EPSP
The EPSP reduction is an artifact of the recording method
The inhibitory input releases an excitotoxin that damages postsynaptic receptors
questions.explanation: This demonstrates shunting inhibition (also called 'divisive inhibition' or 'silent inhibition'), a powerful form of synaptic inhibition that operates without producing a visible IPSP. When ECl equals the resting potential (ECl = Vm = -70 mV), opening GABA_A (or glycine) Cl- channels produces no net Cl- flux and no voltage change. However, the opened Cl- channels dramatically increase the membrane conductance (reduce input resistance, Rm). According to Ohm's law, V = I × R: the same excitatory synaptic current (I) now produces a smaller voltage change (V) because R is reduced. The Cl- conductance provides a low-resistance 'shunt' pathway that diverts excitatory current, clamping the membrane near ECl and opposing depolarization. Shunting inhibition is particularly effective when the inhibitory synapse is located between the excitatory synapse and the axon hillock, creating an electrical 'roadblock.' This form of inhibition is especially important in cortical circuits where it provides divisive normalization of neural responses.

questions.question: A researcher observes that a mutation in a synaptic protein reduces evoked EPSC amplitude by 50% but does not change mEPSC amplitude or frequency. The paired-pulse ratio (PPR) is unchanged. What type of molecular defect would produce this phenotype?
options: A defect in stimulus-secretion coupling (e.g., reduced Ca2+ channel-vesicle coupling distance) that decreases evoked release probability without affecting spontaneous release or vesicle pool size, since the unchanged mEPSC amplitude indicates normal postsynaptic function and unchanged PPR suggests the probability change affects all release sites equally
Complete loss of all synaptic vesicles
Destruction of the postsynaptic density
Reduced postsynaptic receptor number
questions.explanation: This phenotype analysis uses the logic of quantal analysis: (1) Normal mEPSC amplitude: Each quantum (single vesicle) produces a normal postsynaptic response → postsynaptic receptors are normal (ruling out reduced receptor number). (2) Normal mEPSC frequency: Spontaneous release rate is normal → number of functional release sites and spontaneous fusion machinery are intact. (3) Reduced evoked EPSC: Fewer vesicles released per action potential → reduced evoked release probability (Pr). (4) Unchanged PPR: PPR typically changes inversely with Pr. If the mutation reduces Pr at all synapses equally (e.g., by affecting Ca2+ channel distance from the release site at all active zones), the relative change in Pr between the first and second pulse remains the same, so PPR is preserved. This pattern is consistent with a defect in Ca2+ channel-vesicle coupling — for example, a mutation in RIM-BP that increases the distance between Cav2.1 and the release machinery, requiring more global Ca2+ for fusion.

questions.question: To test whether a specific synapse undergoes LTP, a researcher needs to demonstrate persistent strengthening of synaptic transmission. What is the standard experimental protocol for inducing and measuring LTP at hippocampal CA1 synapses?
options: Record baseline evoked field EPSPs (fEPSPs) in stratum radiatum for 15-20 minutes by stimulating Schaffer collaterals, then deliver a high-frequency stimulation protocol (e.g., 100 Hz for 1 second or theta-burst stimulation), and monitor fEPSP slope for 30-60 minutes post-tetanus to confirm persistent potentiation
